children.subject:
Interesting, but I don't know if I want to push 162 all the way to my final semester given the concepts pop up in interviews every now and then. I was wondering if both Stat 140/127 were necessary if I can manage to take 189 with Shewchuk, and not having to take both would allow me to take 182 at some point. If I had to choose one from 126/127/Stat 140, would you have an idea as to what could be more useful for industry purposes if I were to go down the Data Science/industry-oriented ML path?

I was thinking:

1 : 162, 186

2 : One of 126/140/127, heavier of 161/168

3 : 189, lighter of 161/168

4 : 182, 16B

126, 127, 189 will be the most useful path. If you can't take both EECS courses, take optimization.

comments on your schedule:

1: 162 and 186 will be very difficult. 186 is far more difficult than 161 and 168.

2: 161 is much heavier, and 168 is only offered during fall semester anyways

3: 189 and 168 is good

4: sure

If you want to prepare for an interview but haven't taken the course yet, don't overthink this. You can just self study the material in w/e way works best for you.

Would 168 be more useful in generic SWE than Stat 140 would be in Data Science / ML? The only good thing I've heard about 168 has something to do with the professor being nice or something, but I was concerned more with regards to the content.

Scott isn't teaching 168 anymore. I really enjoyed the content. If you're set on DS/ML, EECS 126 is better. But the schedule I recommended, you can do both.

In terms of useful material as a DS/ML person, probably EECS 126, EECS 127, CS 189, DS 100.

How heavy do you think would 161 + 127 + Stat 140 be? I'm thinking if I manage to land an internship before Spring semester starts (a tall order, but nonetheless), I won't have to focus on grinding leetcode / applying for internships / recruiting, so I will have quite a bit more time to dedicate to coursework. In that case, could taking these three technicals and doing well in them be doable? I'm not good with CS 70 style math either so if Stat 140 is similar to the last 1/3rd of 70 then that will make it especially harder.
(For what it's worth, I'm considering taking those 3 next Spring if everything else in my life works out)
And if you think that's doable, then I can make room for 168 Senior Fall too.

history.content:
Big mistake. 16B sets the groundwork for EE127 and many other mathy things in EECS. Don't push it. Especially if you want to do ML, 16B is surprisingly useful.

On the other hand, if you don't want to do ML, you can take 189, 182, 126 and 127 all off your list.

children.subject:
I'm familiar with the relevant 16B content for the most part, especially SVD/PCA and K-means. @Student answer. 

I'm just not a big fan of circuits.

history.content:
I have 4 more semesters left and was looking to take 2 CS/EE courses a semester max. Some of the courses I was interested in and/or had remaining were as follows:

EE 16B (requirement - will take Spring 2021)

CS 162

CS 186

CS 189

CS 182

CS 161

CS 168 

CS 169 

EECS 127

Stat 140 / EECS 126 (1 of the 2, currently leaning towards 140 since 126 seems too rough)

I was trying to divide most of (can't really take all 10 unless I take 3 CS courses at some point which I have found I am unable to manage) these courses such that I can optimize for 1) workload and 2) taking those most useful in industry as soon as possible (especially for internships, the interviews for some of which require Databases/OS/Networking knowledge as I have found out the hard way). If anyone has any advice on how I should split these courses up given these constraints, and/or has had experience with certain orderings/combos that they would like to advise for/against, that would be much appreciated. Thanks.
history.subject: Potential Schedule Advice?
